results.traffic_offense: Getting On or Off a Moving Vehicle
results.simplified: You should not get on or off a moving vehicle (except motor cycles), and the driver or person in charge of a vehicle should not allow anyone to do so.

results.traffic_offense: Holding On to Another Moving Vehicle
results.simplified: You should not hold on to a moving vehicle such that it tows or draws another vehicle, and the driver or person in charge of a vehicle should not allow anyone to do so.

A vehicle cannot be towed unless a person with a driving license is sitting in the driver's seat, or unless the vehicle is being towed by crane.

results.traffic_offense: Sitting on Seat Reserved for Women
results.simplified: If you sit on a seat reserved for a woman without any lawful excuse, you may be asked to get off from the vehicle without any refund of the fare. Refusing to do so would lead to a fine.

results.traffic_offense: Conduct of Driver of Transport Vehicle
results.simplified:
The driver of a transport vehicle :
(i) shall not smoke
(ii) cannot ask for customers in a loud or uncivil manner 
(iii) should not be drunk

results.traffic_offense: Conduct of a Conductor of Public Transport Vehicles
results.simplified:
The conductor of a public transport vehicle: 
(i) shall not smoke while on duty 
(ii) cannot ask for customers in a loud or uncivil manner
(iii) cannot, without any good reason, refuse to take a passenger who is ready to pay for the ticket
(iv) cannot let a person on the vehicle if they haven't paid for the ticket. 
(iv)  cannot, without any good reason, ask a passenger who has paid for his ticket to get off from the vehicle before the journey has ended
(v) cannot be intoxicated in any way that hampers his ability to do his job
(vi) should prevent any person from getting on to the vehicle who is, or seems to be intoxicated 
(vii) cannot allow the vehicle to be used for any illegal or immoral objectives

results.simplified: You can be punished if you don’t follow Traffic Signals, Traffic Lights, or the directions of a Police Officer in Uniform

If your vehicle is involved in an accident, anyone who has been injured must be taken to the nearest medical facility. Unless prevented by mob fury, or any other factor beyond control, you must take all reasonable steps to get treatment for the injured.

If your vehicle has been involved in an accident causing injury or damage to property of someone else, you must provide any information required by a police officer.
If no officer is present, you must report to the nearest police station within 24 hours, the circumstances of the accident, and if medical aid was not provided.

results.traffic_offense: Duty of Doctors to Treat without Procedural Formalities
results.simplified: Unless the injured person or her guardian refuses, doctors must provide all necessary medical aid without waiting for procedural formalities

You will be punished if your blood alcohol content is more than 30mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood, or if you have taken any drug that makes you incapable of driving properly.

Note: A Committee of the Supreme Court has issued guidelines to all states according to which your license can be suspended for more than 3 months if you drive a vehicle under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Further, the guidelines state the police are encouraged to try and put you in jail even for the first offense.

You should not drive at such a speed, or in such a way that is dangerous to the public.

Note: A Committee of the Supreme Court has issued guidelines to states according to which both main and pillion riders should follow the rules regarding helmets. If you (as the main rider or pillion rider) violate the rule, you can be sent to compulsory road safety education and counselling in addition to being asked to pay the fine.

You should wear seatbelts if your vehicle has them.

Note: A Committee of the Supreme Court has issued guidelines to states according to which you can be sent to compulsory road safety education and counselling in addition to being asked to pay the fine.

results.traffic_offense: Driving when Physically or Mentally Unfit

If you employ someone to drive, or in any way control how someone drives, the vehicle should not be faster than the maximum speed, or slower than the minimum speed for that road.

results.traffic_offense: Disobeying Directions by Traffic Police Officers
results.simplified: You should not disobey the directions of a traffic police officer.

You should obey all lawful directions given by Traffic Police Officers, or other authorities under this Act. You should not obstruct or prevent any person from performing their functions under this Act.

You should not overtake a car when - 
(i) it can cause problems for other cars 
(ii) if you are at a corner or bend, where you can't see the road ahead 
(iii) If the person behind you is overtaking 
(iv) if the driver ahead has not signalled you
If a vehicle is overtaking you, you must not increase your speed, or in any way try to prevent the vehicle from passing.
You should not drive on the right side of road.
You should not drive in the opposite direction on a ‘One Way’ road.
You should not take ‘U’ turns if the road is very busy, or if specifically prohibited on that road.
You should not leave your vehicle or trailer on the road  in a position that can cause danger, obstruction or inconvenience to othe

You should not leave your vehicle stationary in a public place unless there is a person with a valid license sitting in the driver’s seat, or unless the engine has been turned off and the brakes have been properly applied.

Your windscreen and rear window should not be tinted such that less than 70% light comes in.
Your side windows should not be tinted such that less than 50% light comes in.
You shouldn’t let a person sit or stand, or keep something in any way that affects the driver’s control over the vehicle
You should not drive in a public place without a valid driving license.
You should not let someone drive your vehicle if they aren't old enough, or if they don’t have a license.
You can be punished for driving, or having someone drive your vehicle if it has not been properly insured.

You should not refuse if a police officer in uniform asks you to show them your license.
In case you have already given your license to another officer or authority, you must provide any receipt, acknowledgment or proof that the license has been submitted somewhere else.

results.traffic_offense: Failing to produce Insurance Certificate  or Permit
results.simplified: If asked by a registering authority, or any officer of the Motor Vehicles Department, you must produce the certificate of insurance for your vehicle. If you do not have any of these documents at the time, you must provide attested photocopies within 15 days.

results.traffic_offense: Failure to Carry or Produce ‘Pollution Under Control’ Certificate
results.simplified: After one year from the date of registration, your vehicle should always carry a valid PUC certificate, and you must produce it when demanded by an officer.

results.traffic_offense: Failing to Produce Driving License - Conductor
results.simplified: If asked by an authorized officer of the Motor Vehicles Department, the conductor must allow him to examine the license.

You should not drive, or have someone drive your vehicle if:
a) it hasn’t been registered,
b) it does not have a valid registration certificate
c) it does not display the registration mark

results.traffic_offense: Withholding Information, or Providing False Information
results.simplified: You should not withhold any information, or provide false information when you you are required to provide it under this Act.

You should not drive a transport vehicle unless your license specifically allows you to do so. However, this isn't needed if you drive a motor cab or motor cycle hired for your own use or rented under a government scheme.

If a driver or conductor of your vehicle has been accused of an offence under this Act, you cannot refuse to provide all information you have, or can reasonably gather, regarding his/her name, address or license.

If you are disqualified from holding or obtaining a license, you must not :
a) drive any motor vehicle
b) apply for, or obtain a license

You cannot travel on any transport vehicle without a proper pass or ticket. You must obtain a pass or ticket before you enter the the vehicle, or obtain one from the conductor/driver as soon as you enter.
If a Taxi or Auto driver refuses to ply the vehicle or does not carry the passengers, he shall be fined.
No vehicle can be without a horn, or a similar device specified by the Bureau of Indian Standards.
No vehicle can be without a silencer which can limit the sound made by the vehicle’s exhaust.
If you are still learning how to drive, your vehicle must have an ‘L’ sign in red on a white background

results.traffic_offense: Carrying People Outside the Body of the Vehicle
results.simplified: You cannot carry anyone, or allow anyone to be carried on the running board of your vehicle, or anywhere outside the body of the your vehicle.

results.traffic_offense: Traveling Outside the Body of the Vehicle
results.simplified: No person shall travel on the running board or on the top or on the bonnet of a motor vehicle.

results.traffic_offense: Driving Vehicle that Violates Safety or Pollution Standards
results.simplified: You can be punished for driving, or having someone drive a vehicle that violates standards related to road safety, or noise and air pollution.
You can be punished for entering, mounting, or tampering with a stationary vehicle without lawful authority or reasonable excuse.

results.traffic_offense: Taking Vehicle without Authority or Consent
results.simplified:
You cannot take or drive away someone else’s vehicle unless:
a) you have the owner’s consent, or lawful authority to do so
b) you had a reasonable belief that you had lawful authority
c) you had reasonable belief that the owner would have consented if asked.
